questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the psychiatrist with a complaint of hearing voices that are not heard by others. The patient states that these voices are commenting on his actions and behavior. Based on this information, which of the following criteria supports the diagnosis of hallucinations in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient can control the occurrence of the "voices".

options.label: B
options.text: The voices come from inside the ‘mind’ of the patient

options.label: C
options.text: The voices are experienced as vivid and clear, with a sense of external origin.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient is consciously fabricating the experience.

questions.correct_answer: C. The voices are experienced as vivid and clear, with a sense of external origin.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The voices are experienced as vivid and clear, with a sense of external origin.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The patient can control the occurrence of the voices: Hallucinations are typically involuntary experiences , and the individual experiencing them usually cannot control their occurrence . Therefore, this criterion does not support the diagnosis of hallucinations.
  • • Option A. The patient can control the occurrence of the voices:
  • • Hallucinations
  • • involuntary experiences
  • • individual experiencing them usually cannot control their occurrence
  • • Option B. The voices coming from inside the ‘mind' suggest that the voices are coming from a ‘subjective space’. Hallucinations originate from an ‘objective space’ . Therefore, this criterion does not support the diagnosis of hallucinations.
  • • Option B. The voices coming from inside the ‘mind' suggest that the voices are coming from a ‘subjective space’.
  • • ‘objective space’
  • • Option D. The patient is consciously fabricating the experience: If a patient is consciously fabricating the experience , it would be considered malingering or factitious disorder , not a hallucination. Hallucinations are involuntary experiences and are not produced intentionally by the individual experiencing them.
  • • Option D. The patient is consciously fabricating the experience:
  • • patient is consciously fabricating the experience
  • • considered malingering or factitious disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hallucinations are sensory perceptions that occur in the absence of external stimuli and are typically experienced as real and vivid as actual sensory perceptions. They are experienced in outer objective space and they are not under willful control . They can involve various sensory modalities, including auditory, visual, tactile, olfactory, and gustatory.

  • ➤ sensory perceptions
  • ➤ absence of external stimuli
  • ➤ real and vivid
  • ➤ outer objective space
  • ➤ not under willful control

questions.text: A 19 year old female presents to psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive, intrusive thoughts about contamination and repetitive washing, for last 1 year. The patient was diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder and her treatment was started. Obsessions are disturbances of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Possession of thought.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In disturbances of possession of thought, patients experience that their thoughts are being manipulated by others or that they have lost control over their own thoughts. A patient with obsessions gets a thought repeatedly and feels that he has lost control over his thoughts. Hence obsessions are considered as disturbances of possession of thought.
  • ➤ Please note : While some sources may classify obsessions as disorders of content of thought, Fish's Clinical Psychopathology (a definitive authority in this field) clearly describes obsessions as disorders of possession of thought, making it the best answer. This classification is well-established and accepted by the vast majority of faculty in psychiatric education

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the psychiatric clinic by local authorities after being detained for harassing his wife. On evaluation, he consistently asserts that his wife has been unfaithful to him, recounting elaborate tales of her supposed escapades. His wife, accompanied by friends and family, provides evidence to the contrary, including video footage and testimonials showing her whereabouts at all times. Despite this evidence, the man remains unyielding in his belief. Which of the following best describes the nature of his thought disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Disorder of thought content.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Disorder of possession of thought: Involves the feeling that one's thoughts are being intruded upon or controlled by external forces . Examples include obsessions or thought alienation. The patient does not describe such experiences.
  • • Option B: Disorder of possession of thought:
  • • Involves the feeling that one's thoughts are being intruded upon or controlled by external forces
  • • Option C: Disorder of form of thought: Reflects abnormalities in the organization of thinking or association between consecutive thoughts . Examples include tangentiality or loosening of associations. The patient's focus remains on his wife's supposed infidelity, without exhibiting these thought abnormalities.
  • • Option C: Disorder of form of thought:
  • • abnormalities in the organization of thinking or association between consecutive thoughts
  • • Option D: Disorder of stream of thought: Relates to the speed with which thoughts follow each other of thinking, such as flight of ideas or inhibition of thinking . The patient's primary concern is the content, not the speed or continuity of his thoughts.
  • • Option D: Disorder of stream of thought:

  • • blood urea nitrogen
  • • creatinine
  • • not specific for diagnosing NMS

Thyroid function tests: Although thyroid dysfunction can present with altered mental status and autonomic instability , the presence of fever and muscle rigidity in this case strongly suggests NMS . Thyroid function tests may be considered in the differential diagnosis, but they are not the priority investigation in this specific clinical scenario.

  • • present with altered mental status and autonomic instability
  • • presence of fever and muscle rigidity in this case strongly suggests NMS
  • • not the priority investigation

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese female patient with schizophrenia is currently being treated with risperidone. She has recently developed galactorrhea. What should be the next step in her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Switch to aripiprazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Switch to olanzapine: While olanzapine is a second-generation antipsychotic with a lower risk of hyperprolactinemia compared to risperidone , it is associated with a higher risk of weight gain and metabolic side effects . Given the patient's obesity, olanzapine may not be the best choice.
  • • Option A. Switch to olanzapine:
  • • second-generation antipsychotic with a lower risk of hyperprolactinemia compared to risperidone
  • • higher risk of weight gain and metabolic side effects
  • • Option B. Switch to haloperidol: Haloperidol is a first-generation antipsychotic that can also cause hyperprolactinemia , and it has a higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects compared to second-generation antipsychotics . Switching to haloperidol may not alleviate the patient's galactorrhea and could introduce additional side effects.
  • • Option B. Switch to haloperidol:
  • • first-generation antipsychotic that can also cause hyperprolactinemia
  • • higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects compared to second-generation antipsychotics
  • • Option C. Switch to amisulpride: Amisulpride is another second-generation antipsychotic that can cause hyperprolactinemia. Switching to amisulpride may not effectively address the patient's galactorrhea and could potentially exacerbate the issue.
  • • Option C. Switch to amisulpride:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Hyperprolactinemia can occur secondary to antipsychotic use due to blockage of D2 receptors in the tuberoinfundibular tract . Clinical features include galactorrhea, menstrual disturbances in females and gynecomastia, impotence in males. Drug of choice is aripiprazole .

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the differences between typical and atypical antipsychotics is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Typical antipsychotics primarily target dopamine D2 receptors, while atypical antipsychotics target both dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors.

options.label: B
options.text: Atypical antipsychotics generally have a lower risk of extrapyramidal side effects compared to typical antipsychotics.

options.label: C
options.text: Atypical antipsychotics are more effective in treating negative symptoms of schizophrenia than typical antipsychotics.

options.label: D
options.text: Typical antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing metabolic side effects compared to atypical antipsychotics.

questions.correct_answer: D. Typical antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing metabolic side effects compared to atypical antipsychotics.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Typical antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing metabolic side effects compared to atypical antipsychotics.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Typical and atypical antipsychotics differ in their mechanism of action , side effect profiles, and effectiveness in treating various symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • • Typical and atypical antipsychotics differ in their mechanism of action
  • • Option A. This statement is true . Typical antipsychotics primarily target dopamine D2 receptors , which helps treat positive symptoms of schizophrenia , such as hallucinations and delusions. Atypical antipsychotics, on the other hand, target both dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors. This broader mechanism of action allows atypical antipsychotics to address both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • true
  • • Typical antipsychotics primarily target dopamine D2 receptors
  • • treat positive symptoms of schizophrenia
  • • Option B. This statement is also true . Atypical antipsychotics have a lower risk of causing extrapyramidal side effects (EPS), such as tardive dyskinesia, dystonia, and drug induced parkinsonism, compared to typical antipsychotics. This is one of the main reasons why atypical antipsychotics are generally preferred over typical antipsychotics as the first line treatment of schizophrenia.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • true
  • • Atypical antipsychotics
  • • lower risk of causing extrapyramidal side effects
  • • Option C. This statement is true as well . Atypical antipsychotics are more effective in treating negative symptoms of schizophrenia , such as apathy, anhedonia, and affective flattening, compared to typical antipsychotics. The effectiveness of atypical antipsychotics in treating negative symptoms of schizophrenia is believed to be mediated by their action on both dopamine and serotonin receptors. Specifically, the antagonism of serotonin 5-HT2A receptors is thought to play a significant role in improving negative symptoms.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • true as well
  • • Atypical antipsychotics
  • • effective in treating negative symptoms of schizophrenia
  • • The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but it is hypothesized that the blockade of 5-HT2A receptors leads to an increase in dopamine release in certain brain regions, such as the prefrontal cortex. This increase in dopamine can help alleviate negative symptoms, as they are often associated with reduced dopaminergic activity in the prefrontal cortex. Remember, decreased dopamine activity in mesocortical pathway is responsible for negative symptoms.

Educational Objective:
